thread.title: Leicester Mercury published Review: Jonathan Pie, The Y
thread.title_full: Leicester Mercury published Review: Jonathan Pie, The Y

author: Leicester Mercury
title: Leicester Mercury published Review: Jonathan Pie, The Y
text:
Comments (0) 
Spoof reporter Jonathan Pie has had a hell of a year. 
Since becoming a viral sensation in the wake of Donald Trump's US election victory, he has seen his profile, and his ticket sales, reach new heights. 
His live show is filled with all of the things he's famous for - namely blowing his top over the current state of politics, and well, the world. 
As a barrage of volatile political satire drives its way into the audience, actor Tom Walker, who plays Pie, creates a tornado of foul-mouthed criticisms about every side of politics we've got - from a scruffy Corbyn and his take on Labour to Theresa May (or Thatcher's reanimated corpse, as Pie describes her) and her leadership of the opposition. 
Pie's target audience is apparent - the left, middle class who are anti-Trump and anti-Brexit. But he pulls no punches when offering his opinion on his own side either. 
"We are attacking the small things to the detriment of the bigger picture," said Pie as he tells us on the left that we are the reason that the Conservatives are still in power and that Trump has taken over America. 
While elements of the show felt a little out-dated - he spends a good fifteen minutes talking about how much he hates David Cameron - overall Pie is incredible at pulling the room from fits of laughter as he reels off personal insults about our least favourite politicians. 
Just as he is equally good at reminding us just how horrifying things are with commentary on the homeless crisis in the UK. 
As he leaves, he reminds us that we need to "get our s*** together". In a world where politics feels so helpless I think he may have a point.
